            Bio
            I am a quantitative geographer interested in a range of interdisciplinary research questions related to the macroecology, global change, and ecosystem services provided by coastal marine ecosystems. Currently, I am completing a PhD in geography in the Rasster Lab (the joint labs of Dr. Sarah E. Lester and Dr. Andrew Rassweiler at Florida State University). My work combines novel field and laboratory approaches, data synthesis, modeling, and geographic information systems (GIS). I approach my research with the aim of advancing empirical understanding and informing spatial management decisions, related to habitat conservation and restoration, ocean planning, and sustainable fisheries. Scientific collaboration, partnerships with marine stakeholders, and mentorship of undergraduate trainees are all important facets of my work.
            
            
            CV
            PhD in Geography (Expected 2022), Florida State University
            Dual MSc in Marine Biology and Marine Policy (2014), University of Maine
            BSc in Marine Science (2010), University of Maine
            
            
            Research Interests
            Ecology and Biogeography
            Global Change Biology
            Marine Ecosystem Services
            Conservation and Restoration Science
            
            
            Contact Information
            113 Collegiate Loop Bellamy Building, Room 307 PO Box 3062190 Tallahassee, FL, 32306

articles.title: Teaching
articles.contents:
Courses Taught:
Geographic Information Systems lab (GIS4043L / GIS5101L) - Florida State University, Department of Geography
This is a a computer-based course introducing the expanding field of geographic information, as a cross listed course open to undergraduate and graduate students. The course covers topics ranging from the GIS software and spatial data structures to the cartographic principles for mapping, metadata creation, and a variety of spatial analyses. Students also gain hands-on experience with applying concepts and tools introduces in the lectures using ArcGIS Pro. Role: Instructor
Biogeography (GEO4300) - Florida State University, Department of Geography
This is an undergraduate course focused on the distributions (including past, present, and increasingly, future distributions) of species and ecosystems across space and over time. The course is a lecture and topical reading-based course providing students with a foundation in biogeography, and also in various biogeographical concepts as they apply to contemporary issues such as land management, invasive species, and species conservation. Role: Graduate Teaching Assistant
